questions.text: Mechanism of action of inhibin? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits FSH

 

Inhibin is a hormone secreted by the granulosa cells in the ovaries. Its primary role is to provide negative feedback on the anterior pituitary gland to regulate the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).

 

Inhibin specifically inhibits the release of FSH. By doing this, it helps regulate the menstrual cycle and ensures that only one dominant follicle develops during each cycle. This inhibition is crucial for the proper functioning of the reproductive system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increases FSH secretion: This is incorrect because inhibin decreases the secretion of FSH.

 

Option C. Increased estradiol: While inhibin is produced by granulosa cells, which also produce estradiol, inhibin itself does not directly increase estradiol levels.

 

Option D. Inhibits estradiol: This is incorrect because inhibin does not inhibit estradiol; it primarily inhibits FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin's primary mechanism of action is to inhibit the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary gland, providing negative feedback to regulate the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented with hypertension and chest pain. A chest radiograph was taken as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of hypertension in this patient?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and the chest X-ray depicting the figure of 3 sign are suggestive of coarctation of aorta to be the cause of hypertension in this patient.

 

Typical C/F: Brachio-femoral delay – Upper limb pulsations/BP is high; Lower limb pulsation/BP is feeble.

 

Radiological investigation:

 

  • Figure of 3 signs on CXR
  • Inferior rib notching – Roesler's sign 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential hypertension: More common in older adults and usually doesn't show specific findings on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Associated with high calcium levels and bone resorption signs, not directly causing visible changes on a chest X-ray linked with hypertension.

 

Option D. Takayasu arteritis: A vasculitis that might show narrowing or dilation of the aorta or its branches, but it typically affects younger women and would likely show different patterns on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta can be identified on a chest X-ray by the "figure of 3" sign, and it should be suspected in young patients presenting with hypertension and signs of upper body hypertension contrasted with lower limb hypotension.

choices.text: Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused
Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG
Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of patients who have achieved return of spontaneous circulation following CPR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused

 

In post-resuscitation care after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), targeted temperature management (TTM) should be maintained between 33–36°C, not below 33°C. Lower temperatures increase the risk of coagulopathy, bleeding, and infections like pneumonia. For patients with high bleeding risk or coagulopathy, the target should be 36–37.5°C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target SpO₂ >94%: Initially, target SpO₂ should be >92%, and once intubated and on mechanical ventilation, the target should be >94%. Overall target range is 92–98%.

 

Option C. Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG: If STEMI is identified as the cause of cardiac arrest, immediate cardiac catheterization should be performed within 2 hours as it's a reversible cause.

 

Option D. Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg: This is the minimum MAP that should be achieved using vasopressors and IV fluids. The ideal MAP range is 80–100 mmHg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-resuscitation care after ROSC, targeted temperature management should be maintained between 33–36°C, with higher targets (36–37.5°C) for patients at risk of bleeding or coagulopathy. Temperature should never be targeted below 33°C due to increased complications.

questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano


The correct diagnosis is Fistula in Ano. A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the interior of the anal canal and the perianal skin. It often presents as a recurrent swelling or abscess near the anal verge, which may drain spontaneously. The key clues include the location of the swelling near the anal verge and the history of recurrent discharge, making it characteristic of a fistula in ano.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pilonidal Sinus: A pilonidal sinus is typically found in the upper part of the natal cleft, far from the anal verge, and is associated with hair follicles in the gluteal region. It commonly affects young men with a hairy back and is located above the coccyx, not near the anus. The key distinction is the location; pilonidal sinuses are not found at the anal verge but higher up in the gluteal cleft.

 

 

Option C. Fissure in Ano: A fissure in ano is a linear tear in the lining of the anus, usually caused by trauma or hard stools. It presents with pain during defecation and bright red bleeding but not with a swelling or external opening as seen in fistula in ano. There may be a hypertrophic skin tag covering it (Sentinel pile). Fissures do not have a history of recurrent discharge or a swelling appearance near the anal verge.

 

 

Option D. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus and typically present with painless bleeding, itching, and swelling inside the anal canal or at the anal verge. They do not present with the external openings, recurrent abscesses, or discharging sinuses characteristic of fistula in ano.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Fistula in Ano should be considered when there is a history of recurrent swelling, abscess formation, or discharge near the anal verge. It is distinguished from pilonidal sinus by its lower location near the anal canal, as opposed to pilonidal sinuses that occur higher up in the natal cleft.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of pain in his genital area. On examination, there were painful coalescing vesicles, associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2)

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful, coalescing vesicles which rupture to form polycyclic erosions along with painful lymphadenopathy is highly indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2) infection.

 

 

  • HSV-2 primarily affects the genital area and is known for its recurrent, painful vesicular lesions.
  • The lymphadenopathy associated with HSV-2 is also typically painful, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum Contagiosum:

 

  • This is caused by a poxvirus and typically presents as small, firm, painless, umbilicated papules as shown below.

 

 

  • The key distinguishing feature here is the painless nature of the lesions, which does not correlate with the patient's painful vesicles and lymphadenopathy, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV often leads to the development of warts (Condylomata) but these are generally painless and do not present as vesicles.

 

 

  • Additionally, HPV is less likely to cause significant lymphadenopathy, particularly painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV):

 

  • While VZV can cause painful vesicular lesions in the form of shingles (herpes zoster), these lesions are usually unilateral and follow a dermatomal distribution.

 

 

 

  • The genital involvement and bilateral lymphadenopathy are less characteristic of VZV reactivation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2) as the cause of painful, coalescing genital vesicles and painful lymphadenopathy in the given clinical scenario.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 25.12, 25.16, 25.24, 25.44

questions.text: A patient recovered from Covid-19, treated with steroids, now presents with nasal discharge for 3 weeks. What does the histopathological image indicate? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Candida: Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.

 

Option D. Trichosporon: Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with complains of numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the lateral three and a half fingers, along with numbness at the base of the thumb. Which nerve is most commonly affected in this case? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Median nerve

 

The median nerve originates from the brachial plexus (C5-T1) and supplies sensory and motor innervation to specific regions of the upper limb. Sensory innervation of the lateral three and a half fingers (thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger) on the palmar side, along with the base of the thumb, is provided by the median nerve.

 

The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve supplies sensation to the base of the thumb and The digital cutaneous branches of the median nerve provide sensation to the lateral three and a half fingers.

 

In median nerve compression, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, patients often report numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the lateral three fingers. This condition occurs due to entrapment of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel, causing dysfunction in the sensory and motor functions it supplies.

 

Injury or compression of the median nerve at the wrist level spares the palmar cutaneous branch but affects the thumb, index, middle fingers, and part of the ring finger on the palmar aspect, leading to characteristic symptoms of numbness and tingling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the dorsal aspect of the hand and the posterior forearm. It is not responsible for sensation over the lateral three fingers on the palmar side. Radial nerve injury typically causes wrist drop and loss of sensation over the dorsum of the hand, not numbness in the fingers.

 

Option B. Anterior Interosseous nerve (AIN): The AIN is a motor branch of the median nerve that does not carry sensory fibers. It supplies deep muscles of the forearm, including flexor pollicis longus (FPL), pronator quadratus, and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP). AIN syndrome results in motor deficits such as the inability to make an "OK" sign (due to weakness of FPL and FDP), but no sensory loss, making it an incorrect choice.

 

Option C. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies the medial one and a half fingers (ring finger and little finger) and the hypothenar muscles. Damage to the ulnar nerve would lead to clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers, sensory loss on the medial aspect of the hand, and difficulty with fine motor movements due to intrinsic hand muscle involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The median nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral three and a half fingers on the palmar side and the base of the thumb. Compression of the median nerve at the wrist (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome) leads to numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the affected digits without dorsal hand involvement.

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism in men is seen with deficiency of? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace mineral that plays a crucial role in various biological functions, including immune response, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. It is also vital for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, as well as for proper reproductive function.

 

Zinc Deficiency and Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in men can lead to delayed sexual maturation and hypogonadism. Hypogonadism refers to reduced function of the gonads (testes in men), which can lead to lower testosterone levels and may result in symptoms such as decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and reduced secondary sexual characteristics. Zinc is important for the synthesis of testosterone and its deficiency can impair reproductive health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is essential for male reproductive health, and its deficiency can lead to delayed sexual maturation and hypogonadism.

choices.text: Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism
Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is characterised by all of the following features except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occurs more commonly in men

 

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is defined by having four or more distinct mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a single year.
  • This condition is more commonly observed in females.
  • Several factors, including hypothyroidism and substance abuse, can contribute to the likelihood of rapid cycling.
  • Additionally, the use of antidepressants has been found to increase the risk of triggering rapid cycling episodes.
  • Mood stabilizer of choice - Valproate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: This statement is correct. Hypothyroidism is known to be associated with an increased risk of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year: This statement is correct. The definition of rapid cycling specifically includes the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in one calendar year.

 

Option D. Antidepressants increase the likelihood: This statement is correct. The use of antidepressants can indeed increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is more commonly seen in females and is characterized by at least four distinct episodes per year.

questions.text: A patient presented with erythema and soreness on the glans penis and pigmentation over chin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lichen sclerosus

 

Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis that primarily affects the anogenital region and is more common in uncircumcised males. The clinical presentation includes:

 

1. Erythema and soreness: These are typical symptoms due to thinning of the epithelium and chronic irritation.

 

2. White atrophic plaques or changes on the glans penis: Progression may lead to sclerotic plaques with scarring.

 

 

3. Pigmentation or associated lesions elsewhere: While uncommon, extragenital pigmentation can occur in related inflammatory or dermatological conditions.

 

Histologically, lichen sclerosus shows epidermal thinning, loss of rete ridges, and dermal fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Condyloma acuminata

 

  • Presents as verrucous lesions with rough surface
  • Caused by HPV (types 6 and 11)
  • No association with facial pigmentation
  • Shows papillomatous growth pattern
  • No erythema or soreness as primary symptoms

 

 

Option C. Fournier’s gangrene


Fournier’s gangrene is a necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal region and presents with severe pain, swelling, systemic signs of sepsis, and crepitus. This condition is a medical emergency and does not present as erythema and soreness without systemic signs.

 

 

Option D. Peyronies disease

 

  • Involves fibrotic plaque within penis causing curvature

 

 

  • Affects the internal structure rather than surface
  • Associated with erectile dysfunction
  • No association with facial pigmentation
  • No erythema or soreness of glans

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen sclerosus presents with genital erythema and soreness, progressing to atrophic white plaques, and can be associated with extragenital manifestations like facial pigmentation.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.3, indicating acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The elevated pCO2 of 60 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) points to a respiratory cause of the acidosis, specifically respiratory acidosis. In COPD patients, chronic CO2 retention is common, leading to increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels as a compensatory mechanism. However, in acute respiratory acidosis, the metabolic compensation is typically inadequate, as seen by the HCO3- level of 28 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). The inadequate compensation suggests an acute exacerbation rather than a chronic condition, as chronic respiratory acidosis would have a more elevated bicarbonate level (>30 mEq/L).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. The patient's presentation does not fit this scenario.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hypoventilation causes respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis. This choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Adequate metabolic compensation would show higher bicarbonate levels (>30 mEq/L). The patient's bicarbonate level indicates inadequate compensation, ruling out this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute respiratory acidosis due to COPD exacerbation, expect hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation, indicated by elevated pCO2 and only slightly elevated HCO3- levels.

questions.text: An infertile patient came with a history of sinus inversus, sinusitis, and pulmonary infection. Which syndrome is likely to occur? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

Kartagener syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the triad of situs inversus (reversed positioning of the internal organs), chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis (irreversible dilation of the bronchi).

 

The clinical features described in the question, including sinus inversus, sinusitis, and pulmonary infection (suggestive of bronchiectasis), are characteristic of Kartagener syndrome.

 

 

Kartagener syndrome is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a genetic condition in which the cilia (hair-like structures responsible for movement) are dysfunctional or immotile. This leads to impaired mucociliary clearance, resulting in recurrent respiratory infections, sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallaman syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (delayed or absent puberty) and anosmia (lack of sense of smell), but it is not associated with the clinical features mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Although cystic fibrosis can lead to bronchiectasis, it is not typically associated with situs inversus or sinusitis as prominent features.

 

Option D. Samter syndrome: This is a triad of asthma, nasal polyps, and sensitivity to aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). It does not involve situs inversus or the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis is characteristic of Kartagener syndrome, which is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) resulting from dysfunctional cilia.

choices.text: Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout
Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout
Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO3-
Increased excretion of H+

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows pH= 7.30, HCO3= 10 mEq/L, paco2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout

 

ABG shows pH 7.3 (acidosis) → Metabolic (HCO3- = 10)

 

Expected pCO2 = HCO3 +15 = 25 is < actual pCO2 (30) suggesting there is excess CO2 than expected. Hypoventilation leads to CO2 accumulation.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hyperventilation leads to excess CO2 washout: And would have reduced the pCO2 levels than the expected values.

 

Option C. Increased absorption of HCO3: Will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option D. Increased H+ excretion: Will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of metabolic acidosis, compare the actual respiratory response (PaCO2) with what is theoretically expected. Inadequate reduction in PaCO2, or relative hypoventilation, suggests partial compensation, highlighting a need for further intervention to correct the underlying acid-base disturbance.

questions.text: As per United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, Targets for MMR and U5MR to be achieved by 2030 are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 70 MMR, 25 U5MR

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were established in 2016 as a global agenda to be achieved by 2030. Among the 17 goals outlined, Goal 3 is specifically focused on health and well-being.

 

Under this goal:

 

  • Target 3.1 aims to reduce the global maternal mortality ratio (MMR) to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
  • Target 3.2 focuses on reducing the under-5 mortality rate (U5MR) to 25 per 1,000 live births and neonatal mortality to 12 per 1,000 live births.

 

These targets are part of a broader effort to improve health outcomes and ensure universal health coverage by 2030.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals aim to reduce the maternal mortality ratio to below 70 per 100,000 live births and the under-5 mortality rate to 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030.

questions.text: Following delivery, the placenta is being removed by traction on the  cord as shown in the image. The cord snaps and there is profuse bleeding. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manual removal of placenta

 

  • Manual removal of placenta:
    • The maneuver shown in the image is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver, used in controlled cord traction for the delivery of the placenta.
    • If the umbilical cord snaps during this maneuver, it indicates a retained placenta, which can lead to profuse bleeding.
    • The immediate next step is manual removal of the placenta to prevent excessive hemorrhage and ensure that no parts of the placenta remain in the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin: While oxytocin is used to enhance uterine contractions and prevent postpartum hemorrhage, in this scenario, it is more critical to address the retained placenta immediately through manual removal.

 

Option B. Uterine massage: Uterine massage is beneficial in promoting uterine contractions and reducing bleeding, but it will not resolve the issue of the retained placenta.

 

Option C. Arrange blood and Crede’s method: Arranging blood is prudent for managing potential blood loss, but Crede’s method, which involves expulsion of the placenta by fundal pressure, is not recommended due to the risk of uterine inversion and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the umbilical cord snaps during controlled cord traction for placenta delivery, manual removal of the placenta is the immediate next step to prevent hemorrhage and ensure complete removal.

 

Ref: Page 1298, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Loud S1 is a common finding
Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of chest pain and upper respiratory tract infection, seven days ago, presents with shortness of breath. She has BP of 100/60 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 110/min. Chest x-ray reviews an enlarged heart, which appears like a water bottle. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loud S1 is a common finding

 

The patient is likely suffering from pericardial effusion, possibly progressing to cardiac tamponade, secondary to a recent viral infection. This is suggested by the history of an upper respiratory tract infection, the physical findings, and the characteristic "water bottle" appearance of the heart on the chest x-ray.

 

The incorrect statement is Loud S1 is a common finding. In fact, one of the hallmarks of cardiac tamponade is muffled or distant heart sounds due to the insulating effect of the pericardial fluid, as described in Beck's triad, which includes hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus Paradoxus is usually seen: This is true. Pulsus paradoxus is a significant drop in blood pressure during inspiration, common in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Pericardiocentesis may be required: This is true. Pericardiocentesis is often necessary to remove the excess fluid and relieve pressure on the heart, especially if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

 

Option D. Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse: This is true. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure from the pericardial fluid prevents the right atrium and right ventricle from expanding during diastole, leading to their collapse. Echocardiography will reveal this diastolic collapse, confirming cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, muffled heart sounds are a key finding, not a loud S1.

questions.text: Match the following: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SVC - Superior Vena Cava: The structure marked as A is identified as the superior vena cava, which is located on the right side of the chest

 

Option B. Aorta: The structure labeled as B is the arch of the aorta, which appears as a large circular structure in the middle of the chest.

 

Option C. Trachea: The air-filled black structure identified as C is the trachea, which appears as a circular, air-filled structure in the middle of the chest on a CT scan.

 

Option D. Esophagus: The structure marked D is the esophagus, which lies posterior to the trachea and appears as a smaller circular structure on the scan.

 

The correct matching based on the image is option B: A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When identifying structures on a chest CT, it's crucial to accurately recognize the anatomical positions of key structures like the superior vena cava, aorta, trachea, and esophagus based on their appearance and location in cross-sectional imaging.

questions.text: Sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipette is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Autoclaving and 70% ethanol

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes, as indicated by the available methods, is autoclaving in combination with 70% ethanol.

 

Autoclaving is a reliable method of sterilization that involves exposing the material to high temperature and pressure (121°C at 15 psi) for a specific period, typically 20 minutes. This method effectively kills bacteria, viruses, and spores.

 

Chemical disinfectants

 

 

So, 70% ethanol is widely used as a disinfectant due to its ability to denature proteins and dissolve lipids, making it highly effective at eliminating microbial contamination on glass surfaces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microwaving and 95% ethanol: Microwaving is not a standard sterilization method for glass pipettes. Although 95% ethanol can be used for disinfection, it is less effective than 70% ethanol because it evaporates too quickly to kill all microbes thoroughly.

 

Option B. Autoclaving: While autoclaving alone is an effective sterilization method, the question specifies the tip of disposable glass pipettes, where combining it with 70% ethanol enhances the sterilization process.

 

Option D. Hot air oven: A hot air oven can be used for sterilization, but it requires longer exposure times at higher temperatures. This method is less efficient compared to autoclaving combined with ethanol, especially for small, delicate items like pipette tips.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes is autoclaving combined with 70% ethanol. Autoclaving provides high heat and pressure to eliminate microorganisms, while 70% ethanol ensures thorough disinfection.

choices.text: Acute coronary syndrome with low EF

questions.text: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

An Automatic Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (AICD) is used for the prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with various cardiac conditions that predispose them to life-threatening arrhythmias. The indications include:

 

Option A. Brugada syndrome: A genetic disorder that can lead to dangerous ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation (VF): A life-threatening heart rhythm that results in rapid, inadequate heartbeats.

 

Option C. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with low ejection fraction (EF): After a myocardial infarction, patients with significantly reduced EF are at higher risk for ventricular arrhythmias.

 

The device is particularly beneficial in patients with structural heart disease, prior myocardial infarction, and those who have experienced syncope due to undetermined reasons but are found to have inducible ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation during electrophysiological studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class I Indications for AICD implantation:

 

  1. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  2. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  3. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 30% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI.
  4. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 40% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and inducible VT/VF on EP study (EPS).
  5. Syncope of unknown etiology and inducible VT/ VF on EPS.
  6. Sustained VT in the presence of structural heart disease.
  7. Brugada syndrome.
  8. HCM with > 1 risk factor for SCD.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Ventricular Arrhythmias/Chapter 252

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with anemia. What is the most common cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia across all age groups, including older adults. It occurs when the body's iron stores are depleted, leading to reduced production of hemoglobin and red blood cells. This condition is especially common in older adults due to factors such as poor dietary intake, gastrointestinal bleeding, and malabsorption.

 

In elderly patients, it is crucial to rule out underlying causes of iron deficiency anemia, particularly gastrointestinal malignancies such as colorectal cancer. For postmenopausal women and elderly men presenting with anemia, investigations such as colonoscopy or fecal occult blood tests are important to identify or exclude potential sources of chronic blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is common in patients with chronic infections, inflammatory diseases, or malignancies, but it is not the most common cause of anemia in the general elderly population.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia:  A rare condition characterized by pancytopenia and bone marrow failure. It is not a common cause of anemia in the elderly.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome:  A group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells, more common in older adults, but not as prevalent as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia, especially in elderly patients, and requires thorough evaluation to rule out serious underlying conditions such as gastrointestinal malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, which requires routine coagulation profile monitoring. The standard test used for monitoring Lepirudin is the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). In cath labs, when administering in high doses need to be monitor with ACT (Activated Clotting Time) rather than aPTT.

 

This is necessary to ensure the correct therapeutic range is maintained and to avoid complications such as bleeding.

 

Note - There are four parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors: lepirudin, hirudin, bivalirudin, and argatroban.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). It has a predictable anticoagulant effect, and routine coagulation monitoring is generally not required under standard clinical circumstances. In special situations, monitoring can be done using anti-factor Xa levels.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux, like Enoxaparin, does not typically require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. In specific clinical scenarios, anti-factor Xa levels may be measured.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor and is classified under direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Routine coagulation monitoring is not required due to its reliable and predictable effects. However, if monitoring is needed, aPTT can be used, though more specific tests like the dilute thrombin time (dTT) or the ecarin clotting time (ECT) are preferred for accurate measurement.

 

Note - There are four DOACs (Direct Oral Anticoagulants): Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor), Apixaban, Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban (all 3 are factor Xa inhibitor)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lepirudin, a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, requires routine coagulation profile monitoring using aPTT to ensure therapeutic efficacy and safety.

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diltiazem

 

In a patient with atrial fibrillation and bronchial asthma, the primary goal is to control the heart rate. For rate control in atrial fibrillation, beta-blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (NDCCBs) like diltiazem or verapamil are commonly used. However, in this case, the patient has bronchial asthma, which makes the use of beta-blockers (such as propranolol and esmolol) less suitable due to their potential to exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that effectively controls the heart rate without affecting bronchial muscle tone, making it a safer option for patients with asthma. Therefore, diltiazem is the drug of choice for immediate management in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker, which can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Thus, it is not a suitable choice for patients with asthma.

 

Option C. Esmolol: Similar to propranolol, esmolol is a beta-blocker and can worsen asthma symptoms due to its bronchoconstrictive effects, making it unsuitable for this patient.

 

Option D. Propylthiouracil: This medication is used in the management of thyroid storm, a condition associated with severe hyperthyroidism. It is not relevant for rate control in atrial fibrillation and does not address the immediate needs of this patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate rate control in atrial fibrillation in a patient with bronchial asthma, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like diltiazem are preferred over beta-blockers to avoid exacerbating asthma symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best test for long-term control of diabetes? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HbA1C

 

HbA1C, also known as glycated hemoglobin, is the best test for assessing long-term control of diabetes. It reflects the average blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 3 months. This is because the lifespan of a red blood cell (RBC) is approximately 90 to 120 days, and HbA1C measures the percentage of hemoglobin that is glycated (coated with sugar). Therefore, it provides a comprehensive view of a patient's blood glucose control over a longer period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycated Albumin: Glycated albumin reflects blood glucose control over a shorter period, typically the last 2 to 3 weeks. While it can be useful in certain situations, it does not provide as long-term a view as HbA1C.

 

Option C. Urine sugar: Measuring sugar in the urine is not a reliable method for assessing long-term glucose control. It only indicates that the blood glucose level has been high enough to spill over into the urine, which reflects immediate/ recent glucose levels.

 

Option D. Fasting blood sugar: Fasting blood sugar provides information about the blood glucose level at a single point in time, typically after an overnight fast. It is useful for diagnosing diabetes and assessing short-term control but does not reflect long-term glucose control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HbA1C is the best test for evaluating long-term control of diabetes, providing an average of blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 3 months.

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Viral load

 

Viral load measurement is the primary method used to monitor the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in patients with HIV. According to WHO and NACO guidelines, the monitoring of viral load is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of the treatment. Initially, viral load is monitored every six months until the regimen is stabilized. After that, it is monitored annually.

 

The goal of ART is to achieve an undetectable viral load, defined as less than 50 copies per mL. If the viral load is less than 50 copies, it indicates effective suppression of the virus, and the patient can continue with the same ART regimen with yearly monitoring.

 

If the viral load exceeds 1000 copies, it suggests treatment failure, necessitating a change in the ART regimen.

 

For viral loads between 50 and 1000 copies, the issue is often due to poor adherence to therapy, and it is recommended to ensure adherence and frequently monitor viral load every three months until suppression is achieved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD4+ T cell count: Previously, CD4+ T cell count was commonly used to monitor HIV treatment. However, current guidelines prioritize viral load over CD4 count for monitoring treatment efficacy. While CD4 count is still important for assessing the immune system's health, it is not the primary marker for treatment efficacy.

 

Option C. p24 antigen: The p24 antigen is a protein associated with HIV. It is used for early detection of HIV infection but is not suitable for monitoring long-term treatment efficacy. p24 levels do not provide reliable information on viral suppression or ART effectiveness.

 

Option D. Viral serotype: Viral serotyping involves identifying different strains of HIV but does not provide information on treatment efficacy. It is more relevant in epidemiological studies and vaccine development rather than in monitoring ongoing therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral load measurement is the most important and recommended method for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV patients. The goal is to achieve an undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL).

questions.text: A patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide, having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding jejunostomy

 

  • Since the patient is in complete dysphagia, a feeding jejunostomy is the next best step.

 

CAUSTIC INJURY

 

Most common in children or people with psychiatric illness

 

Alkali poison – liquefactive necrosis

 

Management – Emergency → stabilise the patient

 

  • Endoscopy to assess the injury
  • No perforation – conservative management + feeding by NG feed / NJ feed / gastrostomy or jejunostomy
  • Serial endoscopic assessment – usually after 3-6 months → elective reconstruction → esophagectomy + conduit (gastric / colonic)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophago-jejunostomy : Esophago-jejunostomy is avoided in acute setting.

 

Option B. Stent placement: Esophageal stenting may not be useful if injury extends to stomach.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy: Procedures on stomach are avoided until extent of injury is assessed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic came with complaints of agitation, disorientation, hallucination, fever, hypertension, and diaphoresis after stopping alcohol intake for 48 hours. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

Delirium tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that usually occurs 48 to 96 hours after cessation of heavy, prolonged alcohol use. It is characterized by agitation, disorientation, hallucinations, fever, hypertension, and diaphoresis, which indicate autonomic instability. Delirium tremens is a medical emergency and can be life-threatening without appropriate treatment.

 

The first-line treatment for delirium tremens is benzodiazepines, particularly diazepam.

 

In patients with liver cirrhosis, shorter-acting benzodiazepines like oxazepam, temazepam, or lorazepam are preferred due to their safer profile in hepatic impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke Encephalopathy: This condition is characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia due to thiamine deficiency but does not typically present with autonomic instability.

 

Option C. Korsakoff Psychosis: This is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe thiamine deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholism, but it does not present with the acute autonomic instability seen in delirium tremens.

 

Option D. Withdrawal seizures: These can occur within 6 to 48 hours after alcohol cessation but are not associated with the severe autonomic instability and other symptoms of delirium tremens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium tremens is a severe, life-threatening form of alcohol withdrawal that occurs 48 to 96 hours after cessation of alcohol intake, characterized by autonomic instability, agitation, disorientation, and hallucinations. The first-line treatment is benzodiazepines, particularly diazepam.

choices.text: Causes the enzyme to work faster only

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding an allosteric modifier?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Participates in feedback regulation

 

This statement is generally true. Allosteric modifiers can play a role in feedback regulation, where the products of enzymatic reactions can act as allosteric modifiers to regulate the activity of enzymes in the same metabolic pathway. This helps maintain homeostasis in cellular processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desaturates the enzyme: This statement is not true. Allosteric modifiers do not desaturate enzymes. Instead, they can either activate or inhibit enzyme activity by binding to specific allosteric sites.

 

Option B. Causes the enzyme to work faster only: This statement is not entirely accurate. Allosteric modifiers can have both activating and inhibitory effects on enzyme activity. Some can enhance enzyme activity (activate), while others can decrease it (inhibit).

 

Option C. Binds to the catalytic site: This statement is not true for allosteric modifiers. Allosteric modifiers bind to allosteric sites, which are distinct from the catalytic site. The binding of an allosteric modifier at these sites can lead to conformational changes in the enzyme that affect its activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allosteric Regulation
 

  1. Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other).
  2. Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  3. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme (allosteric activation), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme (allosteric inhibition).
  4. In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier.
  5. The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity. If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity.
  6. In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

H/O consumption of a fruit, high fever, confusion, photophobia, unable to urinate are anticholinergic symptoms. Photophobia occurs due to mydriasis in anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.

 

Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.

 

Features of Datura poisoning:

 

 D's of Datura

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death

 

Datura Flowers: Flowers are large tubular (trumpet-shaped) which may be white (alba) or purple (Niger)

 

Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains 50 to 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which bear a superficial resemblance to chilly seeds

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning: Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug, physostigmine [Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity]

 

Below image shows Datura Flower and Datura Fruit

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. While Datura is the correct causative agent, Pralidoxime is not the correct antidote. Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. Yellow oleander poisoning presents primarily with symptoms of cardiac toxicity, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, not the anticholinergic symptoms described in the question. Additionally, Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect. Again, Yellow oleander would cause symptoms related to cardiac toxicity rather than the anticholinergic symptoms presented. Physostigmine is not the antidote for Yellow oleander poisoning.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • Types:
  1. Nerium odorum (White Oleander): Bears white, dark red or pink flowers
  2. Cerbera thevetia (Yellow Oleander): Bears yellow bell-shaped flowers, globular fruits

 

 

  • Symptoms: In both oleanders there will symptoms of heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse) and muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. They are similar to digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine is useful in the management of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and bigeminy.
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies (digoxin-specific Fab fragments) are the treatment of choice for severe bradyarrhythmia’s with hypotension unresponsive to atropine and life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: The 1st sign to be seen in Mg toxicity in a patient receiving MgSO4 for eclampsia is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes)

 

The correct answer is Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes). When administering magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for eclampsia, it is crucial to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity. The first clinical sign indicating toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes.

 

Detailed Explanation:

 

  • Magnesium Sulfate in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is used to prevent seizures in patients with eclampsia. While effective, it has a narrow therapeutic range, making monitoring for toxicity essential.
  • Monitoring Signs:
    • Loss of DTRs: This is the earliest sign of magnesium toxicity. Clinicians regularly check for the presence of deep tendon reflexes to ensure they are intact.
    • Respiratory Depression: Following the loss of DTRs, respiratory depression can occur if magnesium levels continue to rise.
    • Cardiac Arrest: In severe cases, unchecked magnesium toxicity can lead to cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac arrhythmias: While significant, this is a later sign of magnesium toxicity and typically occurs after respiratory depression.

 

Option B. Hypotonia: This can be a symptom of magnesium toxicity but is not the first sign observed.

 

Option D. Respiratory depression: This follows the loss of deep tendon reflexes and is a critical sign of advancing magnesium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs) is the first clinical sign of magnesium toxicity in patients receiving MgSO4 for eclampsia. Continuous monitoring of DTRs is crucial to detect early toxicity and prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

 

The clinical presentation described suggests lymphatic filariasis, a parasitic disease caused by filarial worms. Lymphatic filariasis commonly leads to lymphedema, especially of the extremities, due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels by the parasites. The characteristic finding of limb swelling that is more pronounced proximally than distally is typical for lymphatic involvement.

 

Night Blood Test for Worms: This is the appropriate diagnostic test as filarial worms are nocturnally periodic, meaning that the microfilariae (larval stage of the filarial worm) are present in peripheral blood predominantly during the night (between 10 pm and 4 am). This periodicity aligns with the feeding patterns of the mosquito vectors that transmit the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Echocardiography: This would typically be used to assess heart function and structure, especially relevant given her history of coronary artery disease, but it would not be useful for diagnosing conditions affecting the lymphatic system like filariasis.

 

Option C. Duplex venous scan of limbs: This test assesses venous circulation and could help rule out venous thrombosis or other venous insufficiencies but would not be the first choice when filariasis is suspected.

 

Option D. ECG: While important for monitoring heart conditions, an ECG would not provide information relevant to diagnosing or managing lymphatic swelling due to filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In regions endemic for filariasis, such as parts of northeastern India, the presentation of unexplained lymphedema warrants a night blood test for worms to check for the presence of microfilariae. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce the severity of lymphedema.

questions.text: A mother with gestational diabetes gave birth. The newborn has jitteriness, poor feeding and crying episodes. Which is likely to be seen in the fetus? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoglycemia

 

In infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes, hypoglycemia is a common complication. During pregnancy, the high maternal glucose levels cause increased insulin production in the fetus. After birth, when the constant glucose supply from the mother stops but the infant's insulin levels remain high, hypoglycemia develops. The classic clinical manifestations include:

 

  • Jitteriness
  • Poor feeding
  • Excessive crying
  • Lethargy
  • Seizures in severe cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neonatal Sepsis:

 

  • While neonatal sepsis can cause similar symptoms, it is not directly related to maternal gestational diabetes
  • Would typically present with additional signs like temperature instability and respiratory distress

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism:

 

  • Hypothyroidism in newborns presents with different symptoms like prolonged jaundice and constipation
  • Not a direct complication of gestational diabetes

 

Option D. VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect):

 

  • While diabetic mothers have increased risk of fetal cardiac anomalies, VSD would not cause the acute symptoms described
  • VSD typically presents with failure to thrive and respiratory symptoms

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk of developing hypoglycemia in the immediate postnatal period due to persistent hyperinsulinemia after birth, manifesting as jitteriness, poor feeding, and crying episodes.

questions.text: Twin pregnancy where 1 twin is older by 1 month than the other on ultrasound. What is this known as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfetation


Superfetation is the phenomenon where two ova are released in separate menstrual cycles and are fertilized at different times, leading to the conception of twins with different gestational ages. This means that one twin is conceived at a later date than the other, which can result in an observable difference in size or developmental stage on ultrasound. Although superfetation is documented in some animals, it is extremely rare and largely theoretical in humans due to the cessation of ovulation after the first conception. Nonetheless, it is the best explanation for the scenario where one twin appears to be older by a month than the other.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfecundation: Superfecundation occurs when two ova released in the same menstrual cycle are fertilized by separate acts of intercourse. The twins conceived have the same gestational age, although they may vary slightly in size. This phenomenon does not explain a one-month difference in age between twins.

 

Option C. Illegitimate: This term is not a medical explanation related to twin pregnancies. It refers to a non-scientific or socially defined concept and does not pertain to any biological condition involving twins.

 

Option D. Monochorionic monoamniotic: This refers to twins that share both the chorion and the amniotic sac, resulting from the splitting of a single fertilized egg. These twins are identical and have the same gestational age; they do not account for any significant size or age discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:


Superfetation refers to a rare phenomenon where twins are conceived at different times, resulting in a significant difference in gestational ages, although it is mostly theoretical in humans.

questions.text: Ebola virus comes under which Biosafety level category as given by WHO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4.

 

Ebola virus requires the highest level of containment, BSL-4, due to its extreme pathogenicity and the severe risk it poses to both laboratory personnel and the community.

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies infectious agents into four Biosafety Levels (BSLs), based on their potential to cause disease and the precautions required to handle them safely:

 

  • Biosafety Level 1 (BSL-1): This is for work with low-risk microbes that pose minimal threat to laboratory workers and the environment, such as non-pathogenic strains of E. coli, non-pathogenic staphylococcus, Saccharomyces cerevisiae (a type of yeast) and Bacillus subtilis.
  • Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2): This level is appropriate for work involving agents that pose moderate hazards to personnel and the environment. This includes pathogens like Pathogenic E coli, pathogenic Staphylococcus aureus, hepatitis viruses A B & C, HIV, toxoplasma, malaria (plasmodium falciparum) and salmonella.
  • Biosafety Level 3 (BSL-3): This level is used for agents that can cause serious or potentially lethal diseases through inhalation, such as rickettsial diseases, Q fever, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Psittacosis, brucella, yellow fever virus, Yersinia pestis, EEEV and corona virus (SARS-CoV-2).
  • Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4): This is the highest level of biosafety and is used for handling agents that pose a high risk of life-threatening disease for which there are no vaccines or treatments. The Ebola virus, Marburg virus, Lassa virus, Nipah virus, flavivirus, and Lassa virus, falls under this category due to its high fatality rate and the absence of effective treatments.

 

Note - For COVID-19 both biosafety level 2 and 3 are correct; 2 is for routine testing & diagnostic testing, and 3 is for culture and virus isolation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ebola virus is classified under Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) by WHO, indicating it is one of the most dangerous pathogens requiring the highest level of containment.

questions.text: A patient of rheumatic heart disease who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field vision loss for the past 1 week. What is the probable cause of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO)

 

A patient with rheumatic heart disease is at an increased risk of thromboembolic events, which can affect the retinal vessels. The key features presented are a history of superior field vision loss over the past week, which suggests a gradual onset typical of venous occlusion rather than arterial occlusion.

 

Key Features of BRVO:

 

  • Gradual onset: BRVO often presents with gradual vision changes, which is consistent with the patient's history of vision loss over one week.
  • Superior field vision loss: Indicates that the inferior retinal quadrant is affected, as retinal involvement typically causes a visual field defect in the opposite quadrant.
  • Associated with thromboembolic phenomena: Patients with rheumatic heart disease have a higher risk of thromboembolic events, leading to BRVO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO): BRAO typically presents with a sudden onset of vision loss due to an acute blockage in the retinal artery. It is less common and would present immediately rather than over a week.

 

Option B. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO): CRAO causes a sudden, painless, and profound loss of vision, not a gradual superior field vision loss.

 

Option D. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)

 

CRVO generally leads to a more severe, diffuse loss of vision, not limited to a specific field. It also typically presents with sudden vision loss rather than the gradual progression described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRVO is the most probable cause of superior field vision loss in a patient with rheumatic heart disease due to its association with thromboembolic events and gradual onset of symptoms.

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetic causes least myocardial depression and maximum hemodynamic stability? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Etomidate

 

  • Among the options given, Etomidate is unique in that it causes minimal cardiovascular depression.
  • This makes it particularly useful in patients with compromised cardiac function or hemodynamic instability
  • Etomidate is an imidazoline derivative used for IV anaesthesia induction, and it offers several advantages:
    • Low risk of myocardial depression
    • Hemodynamic stability on bolus injection

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in blood pressure. It also produces vasodilation which can further lower blood pressure.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in cardiac output and blood pressure. It also has a vasodilatory effect which can further compromise hemodynamics.

 

Option D. Ketamine: Unlike most other anesthetics, Ketamine typically has a stimulatory effect on the cardiovascular system. It often increases heart rate and blood pressure due to its sympathetic stimulatory effects. However, in patients with depleted catecholamines or in certain pathological conditions, it might not exhibit this stimulatory effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol and Thiopentone are known to cause myocardial depression, Etomidate is recognized for its minimal cardiovascular depression, and Ketamine typically stimulates the cardiovascular system, but with certain exceptions.

choices.text: Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin
Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+
Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum
Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

 

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is characterized by the presence of Reed Sternberg cells, which are of B cell origin. These cells typically express CD30 and PAX 5 markers. The nodular sclerosis subtype of HL often involves the mediastinum, where Reed Sternberg cells are referred to as lacunar cells due to their unique appearance in this subtype. However, the statement that the commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring is incorrect. The Waldeyer ring is more commonly involved in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). HL typically affects the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells, the hallmark of Hodgkin lymphoma, originate from B cells.

 

Option B. Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells express CD30 and PAX 5 markers, which are used in diagnosing Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum: Correct. The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma frequently involves the mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin lymphoma typically involves the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. The involvement of the Waldeyer ring is more characteristic of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

choices.text: Review USG after 2 weeks
Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks
ECV at 36 weeks
Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.text: A 34 year G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks:
    • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture.
    • A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor.
    • Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks: This option does not address the critical issue of the patient's previous classical cesarean section, which necessitates planning for a repeat cesarean delivery.

 

Option C. ECV at 36 weeks: External Cephalic Version (ECV) is contraindicated in patients with a previous classical cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.

 

Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version: Awaiting spontaneous labor is not advisable due to the increased risk of uterine rupture with a classical cesarean scar. Additionally, internal podalic version is not a recommended procedure in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication to a vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture; hence, an elective cesarean section should be scheduled at 37 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 1439, William Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

The chloride level of sweat is evaluated in cystic fibrosis.

 

CYSTIC FIBROSIS

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Mutation in chromosome no. 7
  • Primary defect: CFTR gene [Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene on chromosome 7q31.2]
  • Other defects: Chloride channels, Potassium channels, Epithelial sodium channels

 

 

  • Sweat ducts normally absorb sodium from lumen which decreases in CF causing salty sweat.
  • Excessive loss of salt in the sweat is there. Other ducts are obstructed.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

Hallmark of cystic fibrosis –

 

High sodium and chloride levels Sweat chloride level is >60mEq/L in 2 occasions Airways, pancreas & GIT - Normally sodium uptake is there from luminal fluid but in CF there is increase of sodium and water uptake from lumen causing thick, viscid secretions.

 

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria occurs due to absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme, leading to phenylketonuria. Diagnosis is made by Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of the tissue enzyme glucocerebrosidase that splits glucose from glucosylceramide, resulting in accumulation of the latter in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. Diagnosis is made by measuring glucocerebrosidase levels in leukocytes or skin fibroblasts. Serum chitotriosidase levels are elevated.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta causes defective type-1 collagen. Presents with a triad of blue sclera, Fragile bones, Early deafness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

questions.text: A wife is complaining that her husband is not taking medications for his diabetes regularly and not maintaining his blood glucose for a long time. Which of the following markers is best for long-duration glucose analysis? (FMGE Jan 2024
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HbA1C

 

Explanation

 

HbA1c, or glycated hemoglobin, is the best marker for assessing long-term glucose control in diabetic patients. It reflects the average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months. This is because glucose binds to hemoglobin in red blood cells, and since red blood cells have a lifespan of about 120 days, the HbA1c value provides a long-term overview of blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. RBS: Not suitable for long-term glucose control as it only measures blood sugar at a specific moment.

 

Option B. FBS: Provides fasting glucose levels but does not give a long-term picture.

 

Option C. PPBS: Useful for assessing post-meal glucose control but not for long-term analysis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

HbA1c is the best marker for long-term glucose analysis in diabetic patients as it reflects average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months.

 

The target HbA1c for most patients with diabetes to ensure adequate control is less than 7%, though this may vary based on individual patient circumstances.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal edema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Terlipressin plus albumin

 

The patient described has cirrhosis with signs of renal dysfunction, which suggests the possibility of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) (Remember - HRS is the diagnosis of exclusion)

 

HRS is a type of renal failure that occurs in patients with advanced liver disease and is characterized by functional renal failure due to reduced renal blood flow.

 

The initial management for suspected HRS involves stopping all diuretics, as they can exacerbate renal dysfunction.

 

The mainstay of treatment includes the administration of albumin to expand plasma volume and vasoconstrictors to improve renal blood flow. Terlipressin is a vasoconstrictor that is commonly used in combination with albumin to manage HRS. This combination helps to improve renal function by counteracting the splanchnic vasodilation that occurs in cirrhosis, thereby increasing effective arterial blood volume and renal perfusion.

 

Doses – The prescribed dose of albumin is 1 gram per kilogram of body weight per day. The maximum dose should not exceed 100 grams per day. Albumin should be administered for at least 48 hours, equivalent to 2 days.

 

It's important to avoid using normal saline or lactated solutions concurrently because they contain sodium, which could be contraindicated or undesirable in the treatment circumstances requiring albumin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylprednisolone: Methylprednisolone is a corticosteroid and is not indicated in the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome. It is used for conditions such as autoimmune hepatitis or severe alcoholic hepatitis, but it does not address the pathophysiology of HRS.

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant and is not appropriate in this setting due to the increased risk of bleeding in patients with cirrhosis. It is used for preventing or treating thrombotic conditions but does not play a role in managing HRS.

 

Option C. Torsemide: Torsemide is a loop diuretic and should be discontinued in patients with HRS. Diuretics can worsen renal function in these patients by further decreasing renal perfusion and exacerbating the underlying problem of splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with cirrhosis and suspected hepatorenal syndrome, the appropriate management includes the use of albumin combined with vasoconstrictors like terlipressin to improve renal function and address the underlying hemodynamic changes associated with HRS.

questions.text: Which vaccine is not safe in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Varicella

 

Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine is a live vaccine that is contraindicated during pregnancy. Live vaccines are generally avoided during pregnancy due to the theoretical risk of transmitting the attenuated virus to the fetus, which could potentially cause infection and teratogenicity. The only exception to this rule is the yellow fever vaccine, which may be given if travel to an endemic area is absolutely necessary.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Influenza: Incorrect. While influenza vaccine is available in both live and inactivated forms, the inactivated influenza vaccine is commonly used and is safe during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Rabies: Incorrect. Rabies vaccine is a killed vaccine and is safe to administer during pregnancy if indicated.

 

Option D. Td: Incorrect. Tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine is routinely recommended and safely administered during pregnancy to prevent maternal and neonatal tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All live vaccines except yellow fever are contra-indicated due to the theoretical risk of fetal infection and teratogenicity

questions.text: Match the Following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  1. Insulin - Tyrosine Kinase Pathway: Insulin uses a tyrosine kinase receptor. This is a cell surface receptor that, when activated, phosphorylates tyrosine residues on target proteins, triggering intracellular signaling cascades.
  2. Growth Hormone - JAK-STAT Pathway: Growth hormone, along with prolactin and leptin, uses the JAK-STAT (Janus Kinase-Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription) pathway. This is a cytokine receptor-mediated signaling mechanism.
  3. Acetylcholine - Ligand-gated Channel: At the neuromuscular junction, acetylcholine operates through ligand-gated sodium channels. When acetylcholine binds, these channels open, allowing sodium ions to flow and triggering muscle contraction.
  4. Levothyroxine (Thyroid Hormone) - Nuclear Receptor: Thyroid hormones act through nuclear receptors, which means they enter the cell and directly interact with DNA in the nucleus to regulate gene expression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classification of Receptors

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent surgery for rectal prolapse, and a postoperative image was obtained. Can you identify the procedure that was most likely performed on the patient from the given image below ? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiersch stitch

 

  • The postoperative image suggests the use of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse.
  • Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal.
  • It is now rarely done due to postoperative problems such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: A minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat internal hemorrhoids by repositioning prolapsed tissue back to its normal anatomical position with a circular stapling device. This procedure does not align with the provided image of Thiersch wiring.

 

Option B. Well's procedure: An abdominal procedure for rectal prolapse that involves repositioning and attaching the rectum to the sacrum using sutures, often reinforced with mesh. This technique does not correspond to the image provided, which clearly shows a perineal approach with wiring.

 

Option D. Altemeier repair: A perineal approach to resect and anastomose the prolapsed rectum. While Altemeier repair is a perineal procedure, it involves resection and anastomosis rather than the placement of a circumferential wire around the anus, as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiersch's procedure, involving the placement of a wire or tape around the anal canal, is used in managing rectal prolapse but is now infrequently performed due to associated complications such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

 

  • This statement is false. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. The circumflex artery travels in the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle and supplies the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

 

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
