  • Right conus artery – it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called, ‘annulus of Vieussen’s’.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than left coronary artery: This is true. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically has a smaller diameter compared to the left main coronary artery. The left coronary artery further divides into the left anterior descending (LAD) and the circumflex arteries, which are primary arteries supplying a significant portion of the heart, especially in left-dominant circulatory systems.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This is true. The RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus (also known as the right coronary sinus) of the aorta. It's one of the three aortic sinuses located just above the aortic valve. The other two sinuses give rise to the left coronary artery and have no coronary artery associated with them, respectively.

 

Option D. Right conal (or conus) artery is its first branch: This is true. The first branch of the RCA, in many individuals, is the conal or conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle. After this, the RCA travels in the coronary sulcus and gives off other branches like the right marginal artery and, in many people, the posterior descending artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for splenectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy because removing the spleen does not address the underlying cause of bone marrow failure. Splenectomy would not provide any benefit in managing or treating bone marrow failure, as the problem lies within the bone marrow's ability to produce blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iatrogenic splenic rupture: This refers to a rupture of the spleen caused inadvertently by medical intervention. In cases of splenic rupture, splenectomy is often necessary to prevent further complications such as internal bleeding.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Splenectomy can be indicated for thrombocytopenia, particularly if it is caused by conditions like Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP), where the spleen destroys platelets.

 

Option C. Splenic infarct with sepsis: In cases where a splenic infarct leads to sepsis, splenectomy may be necessary to remove the infected spleen and control the spread of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy, as the procedure does not address the underlying pathology of bone marrow production issues.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

In this scenario, the patient has undergone parotid surgery and subsequently developed weakness of the lower lip on the same side as the surgery (ipsilateral). This kind of symptom indicates a nerve injury.

 

  • Facial Nerve Branches: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression. It divides into several branches after it exits the stylomastoid foramen, including the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal mandibular), and cervical branches.
  • Cervical Branch: The cervical branch of the facial nerve, along with the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower face, including those involved in the movement of the lower lip. An injury to the cervical branch could result in weakness of the lower lip, which is consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • Marginal Mandibular Branch: Although the marginal mandibular branch is primarily responsible for the lower lip, in cases where this specific branch is not listed as an option, the cervical branch is the closest and most accurate choice because it is part of the lower division of the facial nerve that supplies the lower lip muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Main trunk of the facial nerve: Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve would likely cause more extensive symptoms, including the inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), loss of forehead wrinkling, and other signs of lower motor neuron facial paralysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Therefore, this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of the facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates muscles in the upper face, such as those involved in raising the eyebrows and closing the eyelids. It does not affect the lower lip, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Parotid duct: Injury to the parotid duct would result in issues related to salivation, such as a salivary fistula, but it would not cause motor weakness of the lower lip. This option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to which one of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoxia

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors, located in the carotid bodies (innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve/9th cranial nerve) and aortic bodies (innervated by the vagus nerve/10th cranial nerve), are primarily sensitive to changes in blood oxygen levels. While they do respond to multiple stimuli, they are most sensitive to decreases in PO₂ (hypoxia).

 

The peripheral chemoreceptors respond to:

 

  • Decreased PO₂ (less than 60 mmHg) - primary stimulus
  • Increased PCO₂
  • Increased H⁺ (acidosis)

 

"oxygen sensitive potassium channels" in the glomus cells of peripheral chemoreceptors make them highly responsive to decreases in oxygen. When comparing sensitivity, if you increase carbon dioxide by 1% or decrease oxygen by 1%, the hypoxic response will be much stronger than the hypercapnic response.

 

While CO₂ is the main overall stimulus for respiration (as it affects both central and peripheral chemoreceptors), when specifically discussing peripheral chemoreceptors alone, hypoxia is the stimulus to which they are most sensitive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO₂: While peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to increases in PCO₂, they are less sensitive to CO₂ than to hypoxia. CO₂ primarily stimulates central chemoreceptors in the ventral medulla which respond to changes in H⁺ ion concentration in the CSF. CO₂ is the main stimulus for respiration overall, but not the most sensitive stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors specifically.

 

Option C. Alkalosis: Peripheral chemoreceptors are not significantly stimulated by alkalosis (increased pH or decreased H⁺ concentration). Alkalosis tends to decrease respiratory drive rather than stimulate it.

 

Option D. Acidosis: Although peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to acidosis (decreased pH, increased H⁺), they are still more sensitive to hypoxia. Acidosis is a secondary stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors compared to hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies) are most sensitive to hypoxia (decreased PO₂ less than 60 mmHg), despite also responding to increases in PCO₂ and H⁺ (acidosis).

questions.text: A 20-year-old sexual assault victim was examined in court "in camera." What does it imply? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed proceeding

 

"In camera" is a legal term used to describe a judicial proceeding that is held privately, away from the public and the media. This setting is particularly used in sensitive cases, such as those involving sexual assault, to protect the privacy and dignity of the victim. In such proceedings, only selected individuals, such as the judge, lawyers, the accused, the victim, and sometimes a few relatives of the victim, are allowed to be present.

 

This type of trial is mandated in India for all sexual assault cases to ensure the victim's confidentiality and provide a safe environment free from public scrutiny. It is not a public trial, and the general public is not allowed to attend.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open proceeding: An open proceeding is accessible to the public and media, which is not suitable for sensitive cases like sexual assault due to privacy concerns. This option is incorrect because "in camera" specifically denotes a closed proceeding.

 

Option C. Recorded in camera: This option might seem correct due to the term "camera," but it does not mean the proceedings are being recorded. "In camera" refers to the closed nature of the trial, not to any form of recording.

 

Option D. Proceedings in another place: This option incorrectly implies that the trial is conducted at a different location. However, "in camera" refers to the nature of the trial being private, not about the location of the proceedings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"In camera" refers to a closed proceeding in court where only selected individuals are allowed to be present, ensuring the privacy of sensitive cases such as those involving sexual assault.

questions.text: What is the term for the likelihood that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Positive predictive value

 

Positive predictive value tells that that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question.

 

 

  • ‘a’ are known as True positive (TP): Population having the disease and showing screening test results as positive
  • ‘d’ are known as True negative (TN): Population not having the disease and showing screening test results as negative
  • ‘b’ are known as False positive (FP): Population not having the disease but erroneously showing screening test results as positive
  • ‘c’ are known as False negative (FN): Population having the disease but erroneously showing screening test results as negative

 

Positive predictive value (PPV): Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, out of all those who test positive on a screening test
PPV = a/ (a + b) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FP) × 100

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (cases)
Sensitivity = a/ (a + c) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FN) × 100

 

Option B. Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease (healthy)
Specificity = d/ (b + d) × 100 = TN/ (TN + FP) × 100

 

Option D. Negative predictive value (NPV): Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease, out of all those who test negative on a screening test
NPV = d/ (c + d) × 100 = TN/ (FN + TN) × 100

 

Educational Objective:

 

Positive predictive value (PPV) is the measure that indicates the likelihood that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question. It is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of a screening test in correctly identifying true positive cases.

questions.text: Monkeypox detection is best done by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Real-Time PCR

 

Monkeypox virus is a double-stranded DNA virus, and the most effective method for detecting DNA viruses is through Real-Time PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). Real-Time PCR allows for the rapid and precise amplification of DNA, making it a highly sensitive and specific tool for detecting the presence of the Monkeypox virus in a sample. This method can detect even small amounts of viral DNA, making it the best option for early and accurate diagnosis.

 

In cases where the pathogen is an RNA virus, the detection process typically starts with Reverse Transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR), where RNA is first converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) before amplification. However, since Monkeypox is a DNA virus, Real-Time PCR is directly applicable without the need for this additional step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) is useful for detecting antibodies or antigens related to an infection, it is not the most direct or sensitive method for detecting the DNA of the Monkeypox virus.

 

Option B. Hemagglutination: Hemagglutination is a method used to detect viruses that cause red blood cells to clump together. This method is not applicable for detecting Monkeypox virus, which does not cause hemagglutination.

 

Option C. Western Blot: Western Blot is used primarily to detect specific proteins in a sample and is more commonly associated with confirming the presence of antibodies, such as in HIV testing. It is not the best method for detecting a DNA virus like Monkeypox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Real-Time PCR is the most effective and reliable method for detecting Monkeypox virus, a double-stranded DNA virus, due to its sensitivity and specificity
